Situation1: They are expected to be present at a family dinner or small gathering.
Expectation2: Follow traffic laws and drive defensively
Situation2: Roads are dry with light traffic and normal speed limits
Story: I glanced at the dashboard clock as I navigated the quiet streets, my phone buzzing with another message from my sister: “Don’t be late for dinner tonight. Mom’s making your favorite.” I could almost smell the food, hear the laughter, feel the warmth of being together. But as a taxi driver, I had a passenger in the backseat, tapping his foot impatiently, glancing at his own watch. He needed to get to the train station, and he’d made it clear he was in a hurry. The roads were clear, the speed limit tempting me to push just a little faster, but I knew the rules—no shortcuts, no speeding, always drive safely. My family expected me to show up, to be present, to be the reliable sibling. My job demanded I put safety first, no matter how much I wanted to rush. My hands tightened on the wheel, my mind torn between the pull of home and the responsibility of the road, the weight of both roles pressing down as I approached the next intersection, heart pounding, unsure which expectation I could afford to disappoint.
